messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: edo jidai Goto school secrets book..........
messages.msgSnippet: ... I m sure Milt means the Kanzan books. It s not surprising that Kanzan used these sources, as almost all Japanese scholarship is simply repeating what the
messages.messageBody:
On 12/5/05, Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:
> I will have a look tonight mate. Sorry, I have Wakayama ( 3 books ) and
> the the Kanzan Tosa Koza ( 6 books ), are they the ones you mean ?.
>
> rich
>

I'm sure Milt means the Kanzan books.

It's not surprising that Kanzan used these sources, as almost all
Japanese scholarship is simply repeating what the previous authorities
had to say. Anything else would be disrespectful, right?

I have a couple of these kinds of books. The fact that they were
printed means they were not "secret," even 150 years ago. Much of the
information gets repeated by Wada in his scarce 1913 companion volume
to the Furukawa collection book, which is currently being serialized
for us in the NCJSC newletter (Joly's translation, edited and
annotated by Alan Harvie.)

Akiyama and Torigoye are two that did not follow the conventional line
of thought, and if you've been reading what Haynes - who's in that
"lineage" - has been writing on the subject of Japanese scholarship,
you know what I'm talking about. Sasano was another who colored
outside the lines, but his work has already been discounted by the
powers that be.

Apologies for being tired, crabby, and opinionated.

Craig

--
Craig Harris
Books from and about Asia
www.bridgeofdreams.com

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: edo jidai Goto school secrets book..........
messages.msgSnippet: yes of course, but that s not really what I meant. We have had more time to find more manuscripts and books, scrolls or whatever. Also, Some of these scholars
messages.messageBody:
yes of course, but that's not really what I meant. We have had more time
to find more manuscripts and books, scrolls or whatever. Also, Some of
these scholars of ye olden times may not have had access to books on the
other side of the country ( just speculation ) I don't know about that
but it would be plausible I think. As time goes on, we acquire more
information and learn more and more. I am sure the printing press and
then the Internet have made massive advances in the acquisition of
knowledge.

So, to clarify, I am not dismissing this and suggesting it is of little
worth because it's old. The line of thought was that it is more likely
that this is a copy, and one has to question it's accuracy ( your
original question ). As I said in my last post. I think these types of
books, the originals, would be locked away and under key.

I am working and typing, I could never manage two things at once LOL.
Sorry if my thoughts are confusing.

Rich




Richard Turner
Nihontô Message Board
<http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/nmb>
- /for the discussion and sharing of all things Nihontô/

messages.messageBody:
ye all,
I checked Sato Kenzan ( spelling ? ) multi volumes on kodogu ( Trickie,
you have that set of books )............. look at the Goto volume, page
270 - 272.
Looks familiar ? same book .
So........... if modan authority used this book as reference, I
wouldn't call it an novelty item.

Milt

messages.subject: Re: edo jidai Goto school secrets book..........
messages.msgSnippet: Trickie und all, I don t know but we have to assume  modan  knowledge has to start somewhere in the past...........they just don t spring up overnight. From
messages.messageBody:
Trickie und all,
I don't know but we have to assume " modan " knowledge has to start
somewhere in the past...........they just don't spring up overnight.
From the few pics, I see it shows the number of strokes with the dragon
thingie, inverted double 8 ( v) etc.

Like we wouldn't just dismiss Newton's Principia Mathematica just
because it's " old "......you think ?

Milt

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] edo jidai Goto school secrets book..........
messages.msgSnippet: I have always thought that the majority of these types of books we see on auction sites and at these sort of lower prices as little more than novelty books. Is
messages.messageBody:
I have always thought that the majority of these types of books we see
on auction sites and at these sort of lower prices as little more than
novelty books. Is this incorrect ?. I would have thought that with
technological advances, another 200 years or so of study and probably
access to more material, we would have the best books available to us
now. I would also imagine that any books written with authority in those
days would be rare and worth a lot of money.

And I don't know why, but I imagine all the good data is on scrolls.
LOL, too many movies maybe ?
.
cheers

Rich.
